Hi John

I can remember seeing several contemporary prints showing samurai in the
process of firing hand guns - I think at least one painted by Kuniyoshi
(I shall look into the collection and see if I can locate it).

There is an interesting web site which may provide some background
material and serve as a "Springboard" for further research.  "The
mystery behind teppo (gun) production technology" by Takehisa Udagawa,
Japanese Medieval History, History of Arms and Armory, Information
Reference Research Department, National Museum of Japanese History. 

 
http://www.rekihaku.ac.jp/e-rekihaku/114/index.html

Best wishes

                                Rod Johnson

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: murphymurphyjohn@... 


  In my research into Japanese firearms,  I know the use of arquebus
match lock 
  muskets is well documented, following the importing of the first ones
by the 
  Portuguese in 1543 at Tanegashima.  However,  there seems little (if
anything) 
  on the use of match lock pistols or hand guns by the samurai officers
who 
  captained Teppu-shu, the firearms corps of commanders like Oda
Nobunaga at 
  Nagashino in 1575.  Can anyone enlighten me here?  Prof.  John F.
Murphy Jr.,  The 
  Japan Foundation
